awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Robust Asset-and-User-Aware Dispatch of the Power Distribution Grid during Extreme Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme temperatures can push various power grid components to their operational limits. The available capacity of most generation resources and power system components becomes negatively affected as the temperature increases beyond certain thresholds. Not surprisingly, this temperature-induced reduction in available power generation and transmission capacities generally coincides with increased electricity demand on the system, mostly attributed to the increased utilization of air-conditioning (A/C) systems. Ignoring the effects of temperature on various grid assets could lead to overloading these assets, resulting in reduced lifetime and premature component failure. It is therefore crucial to incorporate the effects of ambient temperature into power grid operation in order to prevent stress on components and avoid blackouts that could result from failure to meet demand during periods of extreme temperature. This issue is becoming more important since climate models project an increase in the duration and frequency of heat waves. Loss of power during extreme temperature conditions is not merely an inconvenience, as it may also impact the availability of other critical infrastructures such as water sanitation plants, transportation systems, and hospitals and other urgent care units. 

In this project, the researchers will pursue a possible solution that involves design of a methodology for proactive dispatch of the energy resources in a distribution system exposed to extreme ambient temperatures. Electric utilities have traditionally addressed the issue at hand through two means: defining dynamic thermal ratings (DTR) for various components to adjust their available capacity based on ambient temperature and, more recently, offering incentivized demand response (DR) programs for remotely shutting down A/C units under stressed conditions. Although effective in many instances, are vulnerable to significant weaknesses. First, DTR are often assigned heuristically or experimentally, and are not usually amenable to closed form mathematical calculation. Also, A/C-based DR is usually implemented based on the contractual agreements between the utility and the users, and does incorporate users' well-being (i.e., the indoor temperature users will experience due to A/C shutdown). This, under severe heat wave events, can potentially lead to negative health impacts especially on infants and the elderly. The goal of this proposal is to improve the effectiveness of both these tools. The proposed solution models the effects of excess temperatures on available generation/transmission capacity of components, as well as on expected reduction in component lifespan due to overloading or operating under harsh conditions. Indoor temperatures at residential homes are incorporated into the DR dispatch by developing thermal models for houses, which can determine the indoor temperature based on internal and external gains. This creates a multi-objective design problem in which the aim is to optimize cost in conjunction with asset lifetime and user comfort. To address the inherent uncertainties in the model, a robust optimization approach is adopted. To ensure tractability of the optimization problem and the scalability of the proposed solution, standard restructuring techniques will be used to transform the nonlinear formulation into a convex, mixed-integer quadratically constrained programming problem. Furthermore, to enable awareness on user conditions, algorithms will be built based on non-invasive monitoring to detect human occupancy and status of A/C units using the aggregate measurements available from smart meters.

por.por_cntn:
Extreme temperature events such as heat waves pose unique challenges to the power distribution system. Utilities may run into difficulties trying to meet the excessive demand, which is mainly attributed to the over-utilization of air-conditioning (A/C) units, at a time when capacities of many components such as overhead lines, transformers and some generators may have been negatively affected by the excess temperatures. One solution is for the utility to take advantage of residential demand response (for instance, by remotely controlling the temperature setpoints of A/C units) in order to lower overall demand and relieve localized congestion in the grid. On the other hand, A/C consumption is necessary to ensure comfortable and healthy indoor living conditions for the residents, especially children and the elderly. Therefore, dispatching the power grid under such conditions requires addressing multiple objectives that may at times be contradictory to one another. 

The main goal of this research was to devise a solution for a power utility to utilize demand response in such a way that overall demand is met with minimum cost and without overloading any components, while at the same time, healthy and safe indoor living conditions for residents are not compromised. This research work was a collaboration between Colorado School of Mines (CSM) and the University of Tennessee - Chattanooga (UTC). The current project outcomes report is related to the work conducted by researchers at CSM. 

Our overall proposed research was divided into three major tasks to answer the following distinct yet related questions: (1) how are indoor and outdoor temperatures and the A/C cooling load inter-related in residential buildings, (2) how can we determine whether a residential house is the right candidate for A/C based demand response, and (3) how can a utility utilize the tools at its disposal, including A/C demand response and/or appliance demand shifting, to efficiently manage the operational costs without jeopardizing the physical health and lifetime of assets or health and safety of residents. CSM researchers addressed questions (1) and (3), while our collaborators at UTC addressed (2) by developing deep-learning based algorithms to determine the operation state and consumption level of A/C units as well as the occupancy levels in a building using measurement data available from smart meters.

To address (1), we developed two models for thermal analysis of residential buildings and estimating the power consumption of A/C units. One was a black box model, where we used time series techniques to predict the future A/C cooling load based on the its past values, as well as exogenous inputs such as ambient temperature, A/C temperature setpoint, and the occupancy level of the building. In the second model, which is considered grey box due to its higher interpretability, we simplified the geometry of the building by considering only one-dimensional heat transfer for one roof, one wall, one window, and the floor. Due to the simplification, this model was calibrated using the building energy simulation program (EnergyPlus).

Utilizing the outcome from (1), along with the results of occupancy detection developed by our UTC collaborators, we then addressed (3) by developing an energy optimization model that enabled the utility to find the optimal solution for dispatching its energy resources (such as community battery energy storage systems) and the residential demand responsive resources (such as A/C units and smart appliances). For A/C demand response, we assumed that the home is equipped with remote control functionality (e.g. a smart thermostat) that allows the utility to remotely adjust the temperature setpoint. This optimization model was formulated to achieve three goals: the overall demand is reduced as much as possible to a level desired by the utility, the operational cost of utilizing resources are minimized, and the deviation of indoor temperatures of residential buildings compared to the desired setpoint is minimized. All this was achieved while making sure that the temperature-corrected available capacities of various grid components are not exceeded. Under realistic scenarios, many parameters in this model are likely to be uncertain and non-deterministic. Examples could be the occupancy level of the buildings or the expected usage of appliances. In order to account for this, we extended our energy optimization to a robust optimal model that is able to guarantee feasibility against worst case conditions.

The findings of this research indicate that dispatching a power distribution system during periods of extreme temperatures requires equal attention to cost, technical constraints of the grid, and the health of residents. Failing to simultaneously consider all three aspects into account (especially the latter two) can lead to damages to the society (by posing health risks to vulnerable residents) or the sustainability of the power grid (by causing loss of life of assets and possibly, premature failure).
